Summary: GC 5/3 Isolated windslab deposits mainly on NW to E aspects + fragile cornices above 950m. Otherwise generally stable. Haz Moderate.
SnowDistribution: No snow below 450m but some light drifting at higher altitudes. Cloudy on the tops at first then much brighter so visibility was good. Variable, South-Easterly winds approx 15mph lighter at times.
Comment: Probably dry for most of the day, most precipitation is forecast towards the end of the day with snow over the higher summits. Strong winds for most of the period.
WeatherInfluences: Overnight, the freezing level will rise to around 1000 metres then fall to 750m, later, rising again to near summit levels. Some light precipitation expected some briefly falling as snow, some briefly as rain. East-South-Easterly winds will reach gale to storm force in the early hours of the morning then easing, becoming South-South-Easterly.
SnowStability: New snow deposits are not expected to be significant. The  milder conditions will further help to consolidate snowpack instabilities. Isolated windslab will persist at higher elevations mainly on NW through N to E aspects above 950m. These localised deposits will be generally shallow with summit gully scarp slopes, gully exits and steep coire headwalls mainly affected. Some Westerly aspects also affected. Fragile cornices will overhang similar aspects. The avalanche hazard will be Moderate.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: Dry conditions prevailed winds were fresh, South-Easterly  which felt quite wintry at higher elevations. The midday summit temperature was minus 3.1 degrees celsius.
ObservedSnowStability: The snowpack has mostly consolidated in many locations. However, isolated pockets of poorly bonded windslab are still present, mainly on North-West through North to East aspects above 900 metres. These deposits are quite isolated and generally shallow with summit gully scarp slopes, gully exits and steep coire head walls mainly affected.  Fragile cornices overhang similar aspects. The avalanche hazard is Moderate.

Summary: LO for 5.3. Windslab will continue to accumulate on W,NW,N and NE aspects above 900m. The Avalanche Hazard will be Considerable.
SnowDistribution: Deep snow above 900 metres due to drifting. Whiteout conditions initially, brighter later. Winds 20-30 mph progress difficult at times when facing into the wind.
Comment: A challenging day is in prospect, with gale force winds and significant drifting.
WeatherInfluences: Snow is expected overnight before resuming late in the period, this will be confined to terrain above 1000 metres. Winds will be gale force from the South-East, decreasing to strong South-South-Easterlies by the end of the period. The freezing level will fluctuate between 900 and 1000 metres.
SnowStability: Poorly bonded windslab will accumulate throughout the period, as existing snow is redistributed. The greatest instability will be on West to North aspects above 900 metres, particularly in steep wind sheltered locations such as coire rims, gullies and crag aprons. North-East aspects will also be subject to cross-loading. Areas exposed to the wind will become increasingly scoured. The avalanche hazard will be Considerable.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: A generally dry day. Winds were from the South-East, initially moderate, becoming strong later. The freezing level was around 800 metres at midday.
ObservedSnowStability: Fresh poorly bonded windslab was deposited overnight and as the day progressed, on West to North aspects above 900 metres. Older deposits containing weaknesses also persist on the same aspects. Areas most affected are steep wind sheltered locations, such as coire rims, gullies and crag aprons. Outwith these areas, the cover consists of unconsolidated snow lying on bare ground or firm snow patches. Slopes exposed to the wind are scoured and icy. The avalanche hazard is Considerable.

Summary: TO for 05.03 Old, firm snow on steep N through E to SE aspects above 800m. Avalanche Hazard Low.
SnowDistribution: A dry, clear and sunny day. Spring conditions below 800m, wintry above. Winds 10-20 mph.
Comment: The South-Easterly airstream continues, bringing dry and clear conditions to the North-West of Scotland. Freezing level rising to summit level during the day, indicating a slow depletion in the snow pack.
WeatherInfluences: Gale force East-South-East winds possibly gusting overnight to Storm force; easing to strong during the day.  A light shower falling as snow at summit levels late afternoon in the West of the region. The freezing level will fluctuate around summit level or just below.
SnowStability: Little change is expected. The remaining old, firm snow will be confined to steep North through East to South-East aspects above 800 meters. The snowpack will continue to consolidate and is expected to be generally stable. The avalanche hazard will be Low.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: Light to moderate South-Easterly winds. A dry, clear and sunny day. The freezing level rose to summit level.
ObservedSnowStability: Remaining snow lies mainly on steep North through East to South-East aspects above 800 meters. This continues to consolidate and is generally stable. Further snow loss was observed today on sun affected aspects. The avalanche hazard is Low.

Summary: SC 5.3.24 Unstable windslab on W through N to East aspects above 900m, thawing elsewhere. Avalanche Haz Moderate.
SnowDistribution: Firm snow - ice on most aspects.  Wind scoured and bare on aspects.  Good visibility.   Winds approx 10 - 20 mph fresh, cooling.
Comment: Some uncertainty in the forecast but likely to be an unpleasant day on the hill. Worth checking with latest forecasts.
WeatherInfluences: The freezing level will fluctuate around 900 metres with precipitation falling as snow above this level. Winds will be very strong, mostly from the South-East but easing and veering slightly to the South-South-East during the day.
SnowStability: New accumulations of windslab will start to develop above 900 metres mostly on West through North to North-East aspects, East aspects will also be affected. Deposits will only be moderately bonded particularly on steeper terrain such as gully tops and corrie rims. Any cornices will remain unstable. Elsewhere the snow cover will thaw and diminish. The avalanche hazard will be Moderate.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: A dry bright day with a temperature of -1 degrees recorded at 900 metres. Winds were light but strengthened slightly from the South early afternoon.
ObservedSnowStability: Pockets of windslab persist mostly around sharply defined features on West through North to East aspects above 900 metres. Corrie rims and gully tops are most affected. Elsewhere, there is a covering of generally superficial snow above 800 metres.  The avalanche hazard is Moderate.

Summary: Moderate hazard. Weak windslab NW through N to E aspects above 900m. Large cornices in places.
SnowDistribution: Snow cover above 800m - some exposed ridges scoured.  Good visibility.  Winds approx 10 - 20 mph fresh, cooling.
WeatherInfluences: A few snow showers overnight. Cold but with a slow rise in freezing level during daylight hours. Strong South-Easterly winds throughout.
SnowStability: Poorly bonded windslab will become more widespread on steep North-West to North-East aspects above 900m. Some very sheltered East facing gullies may also be affected by cross loading. Weak new cornice development expected over steepest lee slopes. Better stability at lower altitudes and on wind exposed aspects. The avalanche hazard will be Moderate.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: Dry. Cold, though less so on sun-exposed aspects. Light South-Easterly winds freshened later.
ObservedSnowStability: Localised accumulations of weaker, cold windslab are present at the top of steep shaded North-West to North-East aspects above 950m; a few deeply incised East facing gullies are also affected. Cornices, some large, overhang many of these places. Better stability in most locations at lower altitudes. Recently wind exposed locations are scoured and stable.  The avalanche hazard is Moderate.

Summary: NC for 05.03.Unstable windslab on NW-NE above 900m. E and W aspects affected by crossloading. Cornices fragile. Haz. Considerable.
SnowDistribution: Broken cloud on the tops with some sunny spells. Wind scoured frozen and bare on some aspects.  Good visibility.
Comment: Very windy day in prospect for tomorrow. Low confidence in snowfall amounts.
WeatherInfluences: Storm force mainly South-Easterly winds overnight will ease slightly during the day and veer to become gale force, South-South-Easterly. There will be snow showers overnight and into the morning; however there is uncertainty as to the intensity. Freezing level around 1000 meters.
SnowStability: Unstable windslab will persist and accumulate further, mainly on North-West to North-East aspects above 900 meters. This will mainly affect steep wind sheltered locations such as gully tops, coire rims and crag aprons. Cornices will be fragile and prone to collapse. West and East aspects will also be affected by cross-loading. At lower elevations there will be isolated accumulations of windslab, this will be mostly avoidable and lie on bare ground. The avalanche hazard will be Considerable.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: South-South-Easterly winds increased during the day to become very strong. Cloud was broken around the higher tops. Freezing level around 700 meters.
ObservedSnowStability: There continues to be significant drifting of snow which has deposited poorly bonded windslab on mainly North-West to North-East aspects above 900 metres. Areas most affected are where accumulations have gained depth around gully tops, coire rims and crag aprons. Cornices are fragile and prone to collapse.  On other aspects the snowpack tends to be shallow and patchy with isolated areas of windslab. The avalanche hazard is Considerable.
